bibl.title: Letter from Paul L. Tate to Albert E. Truby, November 29, 1949

div1.p: Tate believes that neither Lambert nor Ames belongs on the Yellow Fever Honor Roll. However, Tate believes that Lambert was courageous and Ames was a good doctor.

div1.head: Letter from Paul L. Tate to Albert E. Truby, November 29, 1949
div1.p:
I greatly appreciated your kind letter of
October 25th. Your mention of Colonel (then Captain) Stark,
Doctor Ames and others, brings me into a reminiscent mood.--
I feel the spell upon me--and so should I meander on without
regard to your reading time, please forgive me. Anyhow it does
not obligate you to reply to my wanderings.--I will be amply
be repaid should you derive a little interest or amusement in
the reading.

Yes, I am still interested in the old days at Col-
umbia Barracks (and at Pinar del Rio also). Of course I have
been through many experiences since then--things that really
affected my life more, but yet my mind often goes back to the
old days in Cuba.--Something in the Cuban atmosphere--or, per-
haps because I was young, that those old scenes are etched up-
on my mind.

I suppose you have been all over the world, and in
a big war since then, but I'll wager Cuba still stands out in
your mind, too, with memories you won't forget.

I have often wondered what became of Capt. Stark.
I remember he was quite strict. For instance, if at an opera-
tion he suddenly asked some Corpsman who had been admitted,
(after orders to bathe, change to whites, etc.) some simple
anatomical question relating to the operation, and the man
could not answer correctly, he could never get in on another
operation. As Gray's Anatomy was my bible at that time, I was
(2)
fortunate enough to attend many, and it was always highly in-
teresting to watch him work.

He had an idea that the men did not like him. But he did
not know that although the men realized he was strict, that
they knew he was always fair. So, when he left for Washington
the last time, practically broken down from so many operations
he performed, the men presented him with a beautiful dress-
sword, he could not control his tears at the surprise.

I remember once he cut out a growth on the inside of
my right eyelid. He knew I liked an occasional drink, so said,
“Tate, I can't give you any anesthetic for this, so it is going
to hurt, so if you keep that eye steadily to the right, I'll
prescribe a drink for you when I get through.”

“No, hold tight to the Nurse's hand and look steadily
at her, and don't move that eye to the left.”

I did so, but it was rather difficult to appreciate
female pulchritude when that scalpel got going! But he saw
to it that I got the drink in the pharmacy. That is one side
of Capt. Stark many did not know of--he had humor.

Then I remember he had his baby boy circumcised. He had
another doctor do it. But he wouldn't even go inside--Paced
up and down beside the operating room door like an expectant
father! And he was sure angry when they turned me down on that
Steward promotion after I had passed highest, as he was the
one who suggested that I take it. It was a tough exam, too.
Doctor Amador said to me after the oral examination, “Tate,
they became so interested trying to stick you, that they
asked you questions even I couldn't have answered!” Well, I
performed full Sterard's work all after that at Ft. Bayard, and
received extra-duty pay, but I was disappointed, too. I had big
(3)
ideas of what I was going to do in the Medical Corps. But that
is all long ago and far away!

I wrote to Wyeth, Inc. telling them that while I
represented no hospital or library, that I had seen all the
people in the picture, “Conquerors of Yellow Fever” at the
time depicted, and asked if they would allow me to buy a
large copy of it. They sent me a very nice letter and one of
the large pictures, 18" x 20" which I intend to get suitably
framed. I would not have known of these large pictures if you
had not so thoughtfully sent me the smaller one.

Lambert should realize that the established require-
ments for mention on the Honor Roll cannot be broken. But I
guess he has become a sort fanatic on the subject of Doctor
Ames not receiving full credit, and incuidentally himself. I
understand how he thinks.--He of course, took more chances of
Yellow Fever before they discovered the mosquito was the car-
rier, than anyone there, and it probably hurts him to see men
like Doctor Cooke and Corpsman England, for instance, get credit
for # taking a chance that he took every day for months as a
simple duty. Well, he is a discouraged old man with a phobia
that I fear will never be satisfied. What I give him credit
for is sticking on that disagreeable job alone for so long.
I think he had lost any fear of the disease, as some few of us
did. I know that in Pinar we had far more Yellow Fever in the
two years I was there than they had at Quemados, although for
a long time we didn't know it. We also had plenty of dysentery,
typhoid, malaria and some small-pox.--Yellow Fever to us was
just one more disease. Perhaps that's why Jernegan and Olson
were not afraid of it. After some of us had handled so many
cases at post-mortems held by Capt. Godfrey at Pinar, showing
(4)
us it was Pernicious Malaria instead of Yellow Fever, and later
we found those cases were the latter disease, we concluded,
“Well, if I haven't got Yellow Jack after going through all
this, I'll never get it!” --All we nonchalantly slapped mos-
quitoes away, never dreaming that they were the buzzing death-
carriers!

I can understand, too, how Lambert feels about Doctor
Ames. I, too, have never forgotten that other doctors and nurses
had fever patients and lost most of them, prior to the experi-
ments. And other doctors and nurses lost cases in Havana after
the experiment. Doctor Ames lost only one, I believe. The people
of his community should erect a monument to him.

They say that old men always think that the age they
were young in was the best in every way. Well, I don't, there
are many things far better in every way than they were fifty
years ago, and many things of fifty years ago I'd hate to see
come back. But there's one thing I would like to see back, or
the spirit of it. --A Government that would go over and block-
ade that Communist government coast of China--as would have
been done long ago if we had the people of fifty years ago!
Looks like we will never learn.

Going back to Lambert being so sore about not getting the
credit he thinks he deserved--Its remarkable how many people
tried to get some glory out of that experiment. I read in Dr.
Kelly's book on life of Major Reed some extracts written by
Mrs. Warner, that surely stretched things. But several years
ago I read a newspaper interview in which she claimed credit
for all kinds of things which simply were not so. Said she
nursed all the experimental cases! That she, on account of
work was made “Executive Nurse” of Col. Bks. Hospl., and
(5)
many other incredible statements. Now I don't think anyone
there was better acquainted with Lena than I was. We were very
good friends. I used to go over the the Receiveing Ward on
many evenings and we leaned against the railing outside the
ward and talked. I liked her very much and I know she was a
competant trained nurse. So I was greatly astonished at these
later statements she made for publication. She was never
“Executive Nurse” there, but was in charge of the Receiving
Ward for a long time before I left.

November 5th--I dated this letter Nov. 29th and then put it
aside, concluding not to bother you with it. But I was uptown
today trying to get a copy of your book, so thought I'd tell
you about that, and then decided I'd send you this whole long
epistle and let you cuss!

There are several real large book stotes here, (Berkeley
being a literary minded city) but I could not find a copy of
your book anywhere. But I left an order with the largest firm
to advt' in their journal and try to get it for me. I was
astonished at the size of that store. They told me that they
send out thousands of educational and technical books weekly
all over the world, especially to the P. I. where all books
were burned by the Japs, and thousands to Japan, Arabia and
Iran.

With very best wishes for you in every way, and
apologies for this crazy letter,
